title: AP Prep Course
question_text:
Suppose at a large high school, the average AP test score for AP Statistics is $2.84$ with a standard deviation of $0.45$.
The school decided to offer nightly study sessions and randomly chose $30$ students to participate. These $30$ students averaged AP scores of $3.1$.
What can be said about the effectiveness of the AP study sessions?

choices.text: Nothing, since the design of the experiment was not done in an effective manner.
Nothing, since the sample size is too small to develop any reasonable conclusions.
The students in the study sessions did not perform much better than their peers; their effort is only $0.58$ standard deviations above the mean of their peers.
These students performed much better than their peers; their results are $3.16$ standard deviations above the mean of their peers.
While this study shows that these $30$ students did better than their peers, it would have been more effective to compare these studentsâ€™ scores to the national AP average.

solution:
When calculated, the z-score is:

$$\dfrac{(3.1-2.84)}{\left(\dfrac{(0.45)}{\sqrt{30}}\right)} = 3.16$$

A z-score (also called a standard score) communicates how far from the mean a data point is. The z-score is a measure of how many standard deviations below or above the population mean a raw score is.

A z-score of $3.16$ means the students in the addtional study sessions performed much better than their peers; their results are $3.16$ standard deviations above the mean of their peers.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; the students were randomly chosen, so this experiment was performed appropriately.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; a sample of size $30$ is sufficiently large.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; the z-score was incorrectly calculated.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; since the $30$ students were chosen at this school, it makes sense to compare them to the school average, NOT the national average.
